answers.author: Vincent Capell
answers.text:
Hello Alexa,
Most everything comes down to money so unless you are fortunate enough to be able run a city relying solely on volunteers, get as well informed as possible about municipal and economic development finance. It is difficult to implement even the best ideas if there is no money to carry it out. You will want to help your elected officials dream big while also giving them the tools to make their dreams a reality. Go for it!

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
I was in a similar situation 5 years ago. I agree, the budget and finance courses have been very useful. Also ethics/constitutional law. And topical courses taught by practitioners with the most relevant work experience --in my case a cross-listed econ course focused on poverty and an IT management class.

answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
Also, make sure you work in time for an internship with a local government, during the summer or as part of your academic year. Some schools incorporate that into the program directly. Also, consider joining the professional association in your area of interest (management, public works, civic engagement). Most have affordable student membership options and it's a great way to continue to build connections for professional development and job opportunities.

answers.author: Sam Gaston
answers.text:
Internship is very important. It allows you to gain experience and hands-on knowledge about local government. Take classes on planning, urban administration, city-county management or state and local government administration if they are available. Join ICMA as a student member. Good luck and I hope to see you in our profession in a few years!

answers.author: Jessie Levine
answers.text:
I also think it's useful to take a course in human resources so that you will know how federal and state laws apply to managing personnel, especially if you end up in a community with labor unions.

author: Alexa K
text:
Hello everyone,
I am a 21 year old student starting the MPA program in a few weeks and I'm quite excited! As part of the program, I can select a 12-15 credit specialty however, I'm having difficulties deciding what I should pursue. I would love a career in city management and I think I would pick courses that would be ideal for city management or even leadership courses, the problem is that I will be in a program at a smaller institution and the public administration courses are quite limited so I need to be somewhat creative!
I hope that you all can provide some guidance for me as to what public sector professionals deem important/useful courses I should select in my master's program.
title: Emphasis for MPA Program
